comment_data.body:
Thanks for the report.

The long first part is only stray output of (correct) tests for error cases. We could try harder to suppress that output, but they are nothing to worry about.

There are also a couple of "unused code" warnings by the C compiler. They are annoying and thus worth fixing, but apart from that, they do not have a real impact on Cython users.

I just fixed the `DeprecationWarning` in master (1f1aeb8af72ed32307e7ff8ac2390ed930962698). That's in the test runner, so nothing critical.

The last two actual errors are unfortunate. I fixed those right before the release (c485b1b77264c3c75d090a3c526de24966830d42), but it seems that they slipped into the source release somehow. Resolving this would require a new release - but since it's really only the test that is broken here and nothing in the code, and thus the binary distributions and whatever people build from the sdist are all perfectly ok, it seems wasteful to issue a completely new release just for that...

Sorry for that slip. I think the best for now is to disable the tests for this exact release, so that you can build binaries. If these are the only errors you got for the release, it's completely safe to use.

> The last two actual errors are unfortunate. I fixed those right before the release (c485b1b), but it seems that they slipped into the source release somehow. Resolving this would require a new release - but since it's really only the test that is broken here and nothing in the code, and thus the binary distributions and whatever people build from the sdist are all perfectly ok, it seems wasteful to issue a completely new release just for that...

Does that mean the PyPI `sdist` corresponds to a build from just before the tagged version? For now I've added the change as a patch in our builds so the tests succeed.

Thanks for the quick an elaborate reply!

> Does that mean the PyPI sdist corresponds to a build from just before the tagged version?

Yes.

title: Failing tests with 0.28.3
